skill.name: cobrapy
skill.description: Constraint-based metabolic modeling (COBRA). FBA, FVA, gene knockouts, flux sampling, SBML models, for systems biology and metabolic engineering analysis.
skill.summary: Constraint-based metabolic modeling (COBRA). FBA, FVA, gene knockouts, flux sampling, SBML models, f...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown guides and Python code examples. No executable scripts, network calls, file access, or external commands. Safe for publishing.

content.value_statement: Constraint-based reconstruction and analysis of metabolic models enables prediction of cellular behavior. Perform Flux Balance Analysis, gene knockout studies, and production optimization for metabolic engineering research.
actual_capabilities: Perform Flux Balance Analysis (FBA) to predict metabolic fluxes
Run Flux Variability Analysis (FVA) to determine reaction flexibility
Conduct gene and reaction deletion studies for essentiality analysis
Calculate production envelopes for metabolic engineering optimization
Sample feasible flux spaces to explore metabolic capabilities
Build and modify genome-scale metabolic models from scratch
limitations: Requires installation of cobrapy Python library and linear programming solver
Does not perform dynamic metabolic simulations
Does not include pre-built models beyond test models (textbook, ecoli, salmonella)
Does not provide wet-lab experimental execution

use_cases.title: Predict cellular growth rates
use_cases.description: Simulate metabolic fluxes in genome-scale models to predict growth rates under different conditions.

use_cases.title: Design production strains
use_cases.description: Identify gene knockouts and medium conditions to optimize production of target metabolites.

use_cases.title: Analyze gene essentiality
use_cases.description: Screen single and double gene deletions to identify essential genes and synthetic lethal pairs.

prompt_templates.title: Load model and run FBA
prompt_templates.prompt: Load the E. coli model and run Flux Balance Analysis to predict the growth rate and identify the active metabolic pathways.

prompt_templates.title: Gene knockout screen
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform a single gene deletion analysis on the E. coli model to identify essential genes that reduce growth below 1% of wild-type.

prompt_templates.title: Flux variability analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Run Flux Variability Analysis at 90% optimality on the central carbon metabolism reactions to understand flux flexibility.

prompt_templates.title: Production optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a production strain for acetate by calculating the production envelope, identifying beneficial gene knockouts, and simulating the modified strain.

output_examples.input: Load the E. coli model and run FBA to predict growth rate
output: Model loaded: E. coli genome-scale model (iJO1366)
Key active pathways: Glycolysis, TCA cycle, oxidative phosphorylation

best_practices: Validate model feasibility with slim_optimize() before running full analyses
Use context managers (with model:) for temporary modifications to avoid state issues
Check solution status after optimization to ensure results are optimal
Run loopless FVA when thermodynamic feasibility is important
anti_patterns: Running optimization without checking solution status first
Modifying reaction bounds directly without using context managers
Forgetting to reset objective function between different analyses
Using standard FVA when loopless FVA is required for thermodynamic consistency

faq.question: Which solvers does COBRApy support?
faq.answer: COBRApy supports GLPK (open source), CPLEX, Gurobi, and SCIP solvers. GLPK is bundled with cobrapy for basic use.

faq.question: What model formats can I import?
faq.answer: COBRApy supports SBML, JSON, YAML, and MATLAB (.mat) format files. SBML is the recommended standard format.

faq.question: Can I run analyses in parallel?
faq.answer: Yes. Functions like double_gene_deletion, flux_variability_analysis, and flux sampling support parallel processing via the processes parameter.

faq.question: How do I ensure numerical stability?
faq.answer: Validate samples with sampler.validate(), use appropriate tolerances, and check solution status after each optimization call.

faq.question: What are the memory requirements for large models?
faq.answer: Genome-scale models (2000+ reactions) require 2-4GB RAM. Consider processing reactions in batches for memory-intensive operations.

faq.question: How does this compare to other tools like KBase or ModelSEED?
faq.answer: COBRApy offers programmatic access and customization for analysis pipelines. KBase and ModelSEED provide web-based interfaces but less flexibility.
